AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: a medium-sized deciduous tree known for its display of showy, deep scarlet flowers in spring
large, dark green, palmately compound leaves with 5-7 leaflets
red-scarlet, 10” long panicles at the tip of most branches

Over the last decade, the Ruby Red Horsechestnut, Briottii cultivar, has been one of the most spectacular tree additions to the WSU grounds. Beautiful springtime blooms of deep scarlet flowers catch the eye as students and faculty cross campus. The Aesculus genus includes both Buckeyes and Horsechestnuts. The Ruby Red Horsechestnut is a hybrid of ‘Aesculus pavia’ (Red Buckeye) and ‘Aesculus hippocastanum’ (Common Horsechestnut). It has been said the Ruby Red Horsechestnut is the result of a chromosomal doubling. Despite an uncertain genetic past, this horsechestnut is best known for brilliant, large, red flower clusters that bloom in spring. The Briottii cultivar originated in 1858 in Trianon, France, near the famous Chateau de Versailles, the great palace completed in 1715 for King Louis XIV. The Ruby Red Horsechestnut grows to have a nice top with a height of no more than 50 feet. It prefers full sun and does best in moist, well-drained, acidic soils. It tolerates salt, wind and drought. The tree is well adapted to the city and compacted soils. There are no major pests or diseases. It is important not to prune the Ruby Red Horsechestnut when it is young. By leaving the lower branches on the tree, the bark is protected from direct sun. If these branches are removed, the bark could crack and cause problems. Generally, the tree requires little pruning to keep a good shape. The Ruby Red Horsechestnut features broad leaves of 5-9 dark green leaflets which radiate from a central point. A multitude of red flowers come together in an erect 10 inch panicle or flower cluster at the tip of the branch. WSU’s Briottii cultivar has deeper, redder, and even larger panicles of flowers. Bees and hummingbirds can often be found at the tips of the flowers. The prickly, messy seedpods found on the original hybrid are nearly absent on Briottii. Medicinally, the Horsechestnut has been associated in the treatment of swelling and pain due to varicose veins and has been effective in dealing with chronic circulation problems. WSU faculty members Tim and Susan Hatfield sponsored this tree because of its beauty and association with the Ohio buckeye. Susan is a graduate of Miami University of Ohio. In spring 1996, Tim, Susan and their children planted this tree at the southeast corner of WSU’s Gildemeister Hall.
